Archangel

So when an egg and a sperm combine that is not natural? What of a woman that has an ectopic pregnancy is not natural? What of in vitro fertilization used for couples who are infertile?

 
 Besides agreeing with Bassman, let me ask you Matt, do you have fallopian tubes? Not if you're a man. Besides which, such pregnancies ALWAYS FAIL. I don't know where you come up with these imaginings, but you really need to get a clue about reality.
 What is an ectopic pregnancy? 
 
 Ectopic means "in the wrong place", so it's a pregnancy that develops outside the womb. It happens in about one in every 100 pregnancies in Britain, which works out at about 10,700 pregnancies a year. 
 
 Most ectopic pregnancies (95 per cent) implant in one of the fallopian tubes, which is why it is also known as a tubal pregnancy. As the pregnancy grows, it causes pain and bleeding and, if not recognized, the tube can rupture, causing internal bleeding. 
 
 This is a medical emergency and can be fatal. The pregnancy itself never survives - it can't be moved to the womb - it has to be completely removed. http://www.babycentre.co.uk/pregnancy/complications/ectopic/

Besides agreeing with Bassman, let me ask you Matt, do you have fallopian tubes? Not if you're a man. Besides which, such pregnancies ALWAYS FAIL. I don't know where you come up with these imaginings, but you really need to get a clue about reality.
 What is an ectopic pregnancy? 
 
 Ectopic means "in the wrong place", so it's a pregnancy that develops outside the womb. It happens in about one in every 100 pregnancies in Britain, which works out at about 10,700 pregnancies a year. 
 
 Most ectopic pregnancies (95 per cent) implant in one of the fallopian tubes, which is why it is also known as a tubal pregnancy. As the pregnancy grows, it causes pain and bleeding and, if not recognized, the tube can rupture, causing internal bleeding. 
 
 This is a medical emergency and can be fatal. The pregnancy itself never survives - it can't be moved to the womb - it has to be completely removed. http://www.babycentre.co.uk/pregnancy/complications/ectopic/
